results.title: More Winners : The Journey
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Richard Mason and Jane Oehr
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
Justus Zukermann, a wealthy prospector, lives with his 12 year old daughter, Ada on a windswept mountain plateau. Since Ada’s mother died, Martha and her step-daughter, Agnes, have been employed to run the household. One day Justus is fatally injured in a fall. Before he dies he orders Ada to journey south to find her true inheritance. Agnes is to accompany her. Martha (who is in fact a witch) has for years envied Justus’ wealth. She determines to secure the hidden fortune for herself and orders Agnes to kill Ada and steal the map once they reach the forest. Agnes is unable to kill Ada and the two girls are drawn together. After several adventures the girls find a secret cave, unearth the buried treasure and a letter from Justus, which makes the purpose of their journey very clear. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Richard Mason and Jane Oehr

results.title: More Winners : Mr Edmund
results.creator_credit: Anthony Buckley, Australian Children's Television Foundation and George Whaley
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
Twelve year old Cherry Williams befriends Mr Edmund, who is one of the rather impoverished guests at her mother’s boarding house. Mr Edmund has a dream that one day she will be a lawyer. Cherry’s mother believes these are foolish dreams and urges the two of them to grow up. Mr Edmund, Cherry and her younger brother, Sam, save old Mrs Finkel from a bag snatcher. She is grateful and when she hears of Mr Edmund’s dream insists on hiring the Opera House Concert Hall for him for one night. They are all to participate in the concert. On the big day Mr Edmund, Cherry and Sam learn that Mrs Finkel is dying in hospital and that she did not really have the money to hire the Concert hall. Cherry thinks that her mother has been right all along: dreams are for kids. Mr Edmund, however, is determined to have his moment on the Concert Hall stage partly in memory of Mrs Finkel but also as a celebration of hope. Rated: G

results.title: More Winners [Series]
results.brief_description: A second series of highly acclaimed television programs for children. ‘Winners’ and ‘More Winners’ are anthology series of fourteen telemovies, featuring historical drama, comedy, science fiction, fantasy, adventure and social realism. Each film celebrates individuality and the facing of difficult situations with courage and ingenuity.

results.title: More Winners : The Big Wish
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
In the Enchanted Realm the Faeries are in trouble. According to the Charters of the Grand Masters, they must give away seven wishes to the humans every 100 years or they will lose their magic powers. The last wish was given away 99 years and 364 days before. Prince Wilton is sent to earth to dispose of the 7 wishes to a sceptical and disbelieving human and before sundown. The only human being who will believe in him and make any wish is Christopher Walter Pratt (C W). C W doesn’t realise, however, that the last wish lasts forever. The lessons C W has taught and learnt leave their mark on him and those he meets on his journey through a truly magical day.

results.title: More Winners : Mr. Edmund (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: George Whaley, Anthony Buckley and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners”.
12 year old Cheryl Williams befriends Mr. Edmund, who is one of the rather impoverished guests at her mother’s boarding house. Mr. Edmund has a dream that one day he will sing at the Sydney Opera House. Cherry has a dream too, that one day she will be a lawyer. Cherry’s mother believes these are foolish dreams and urges the two of them to “grow up”. Mr. Edmund, Cherry and her younger brother Sam save old Mrs. Finkel from a bag snatcher. She is grateful and when she hears of Mr. Edmund’s dream. Mrs. Finkel insists on hiring the Opera House Concert Hall for him for one night.

results.title: Notorious
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: A compelling drama about human relationships, fidelity, betrayal and guilt. Cary Grant plays Devlin, a secret service agent. Ingrid Bergman plays Alicia, the daughter of a convicted traitor whom Devlin enlists in a scheme to investigate the activities of surviving, post-war Nazis in Brazil.
results.description: A compelling drama about human relationships, fidelity, betrayal and guilt. Cary Grant plays Devlin, a secret service agent. Ingrid Bergman plays Alicia, the daughter of a convicted traitor whom Devlin enlists in a scheme to investigate the activities of surviving, post-war Nazis in Brazil.

results.title: Tristan and Isolt = Lovespell
results.creator_credit: Tom Donovan, Claire Labine, Tom Hayes and Clar Productions
results.brief_description: A celtic medieval story of love, betrayal and tragedy within a 9th century Irish monarchy. Stars Richard Burton (Mark, King of Cornwall), Kate Mulgrew (Isolt), Nicholas Clay (Tristan) with Cyril Cusack, Geraldine Fitzgerald and Niall Toibin. Music by The Chieftains.

results.title: Office killer
results.creator_credit: Cindy Sherman, Christine Vachon, Pamela Koffler and Artfear Productions
results.brief_description: Usually known for her extensive career in photography spanning over 20 years, Cindy Sherman directs her first feature film and brings to life the characters that she has depicted within her photography. Dorine (Kane) is the company doormat, seemingly obliging and mild mannered until one day she accidentally electrocutes a fellow worker, who happens to be her most obnoxious opponent. The unhinged Dorine continues her killing spree believing that all can be friends when dead. Her antics verge on discovery when the bitchy co-worker played by Molly Ringwald suspects that all is not okay. Following in the b-grade genre of film-making, Sherman delights with an excess of gory special effects. Cast also includes: Jeanne Tripplehorn.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cindy Sherman, Christine Vachon, Pamela Koffler and Artfear Productions

results.title: The Taste of others = It takes all kinds = Le Gout des autres
results.creator_credit: Agnes Jaoui, Charles Gassot, Christian Berard, Canal+, France2 Cinema, Les Films A4 and Telema Productions
results.brief_description: This comedy, about the foibles of a disparate group of people whose lives intersect and are altered in unforseen ways, has a whimsical tone that is underpinned by an impressively deft script. Jean-Jacques Castella is a depressed industrialist married to an interior designer who dominates their personal spaces with her ‘taste’. Their unstable marriage cataclysmically implodes when Jean-Jacques attends a bourgeois play (against his will) subsequently falling in love with an aging actress. Clara for her part takes an immediate dislike to Jean-Jacques - considering him a materialistic, middle-class, tasteless bore. Added to this mix is Jean-Jacques’ bodyguard, who falls in with a free-spirited barmaid; his driver, coping with the trials of a long distance love affair; and Clara’s cultured friends who delight in mocking the gauche and unknowing Jean-Jacques. Thus whilst interrogating notions of class and taste, this comedy of manners is also a humanistic and wry portrayal of modern relationships, mores and ways. In her debut feature Agnes Jaoui ably captures the idiosyncrasies and muddled desires of her protagonists, without stooping to bland characterisations or pat conclusions. A contender for Best Foreign Film at the Academy Awards, “The Taste of others” won four Cesars (including Best Film) and was nominated for a further five. Cast includes Jean-Pierre Bacri, Anne Alvaro, Agnes Jaoui, Gerard Lanvin, Alain Chabat, Brigitte Catillon, Christiane Millet and Vladimir Yordanoff.

Cast includes Jean-Pierre Bacri, Anne Alvaro, Agnes Jaoui, Gerard Lanvin, Alain Chabat, Brigitte Catillon, Christiane Millet and Vladimir Yordanoff.

results.title: The Watermelon Woman
results.creator_credit: Cheryl Dunye, Alexandra Juhasz, Barry Swimar and Dancing Girl Productions
results.brief_description: One of the first feature films made by an African American lesbian, this ‘mockumentary’ ostensibly investigates the life of a forgotten black actress from the thirties known only as, the Watermelon Woman. Filmmaker Cheryl Dunye plays herself as a video shop employee and budding film director who begins researching the actress with a view to making a movie based upon her life story. As she uncovers archival footage and conducts interviews with archivists, scholars (played in a series of cameos by real-life experts including Camille Paglia) and women who lived in the Philadelphia area in the thirties, Dunye pieces together a previously unacknowledged history of African American lesbian life in the thirties. She finds that the Watermelon Woman was a nightclub singer named Fae Richards who was the lover of the white Hollywood female director, Martha Page. Meanwhile, Dunye herself falls in love with Diana (Guinevere Turner), one of the customers that frequent the video store where she works. Their passionate relationship allows her to explore her own feelings around interracial romance. The film functions on two levels, as a wry, irreverent look at contemporary black lesbian culture, and as a critique of official narratives that have erased this culture from history. While Dunye ultimately reveals the Watermelon Woman as a fiction, she points out that “sometimes you have to create you own history”.

constellations_other.name: Speaking for herself
constellations_other.description: This constellation traces some critical ways that women have used the moving image as a way of speaking truth to power.
